choices.text: Trophozoites are released in small bowel
Flask shaped ulcers form in the serosa
Cysts are passed in feces as infective form

questions.text: A 30 year old epidemologist complaints of hiccough and non productive cough after travelling to endemic area, serological evaluation proved to be amoebiasis. Following are true regarding pathogenesis except
questions.solution:
The organism enters the gut through food or water contaminated with the cyst. In the small bowel, the cysts hatch, and a large number of trophozoites are released and carried to the colon where flask-shaped ulcers form in the submucosa.

The trophozoites multiply, ultimately forming cysts, which enter the portal circulation or are passed in the faeces as an infective form that infects other humans as a result of insanitary conditions.

Having entered the portal circulation, the trophozoites are filtered and trapped in the interlobular veins of the liver. They multiply in the portal triads, causing focal infarction of hepatocytes and liquefactive necrosis as a result of proteolytic enzymes produced by the trophozoites. The areas of necrosis eventually coalesce to form the abscess cavity.

(BAILEY AND LOVE : 27th edition - Pg 57, 58)

choices.text: A case of Chronic granuloma of ileum
Right sided colonic carcinoma more likely

questions.text: A 30 year old chronic alcoholic female presented to casualty with pain in Right iliac fossa and fever. O/E mass palpable in RIF. H/O repeated episodes of same complaints present. What is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
This is a chronic granuloma arising in the large bowel, most commonly seen in the caecum.

It is prone to occur in longstanding amoebic infection that has been treated intermittently with drugs without completion of a full course, a situation that arises from indiscriminate self-medication, particularly in resource-poor countries.

An amoeboma should be suspected when a patient from an endemic area with generalised ill health and pyrexia has a mass in the right iliac fossa with a history of blood-stained mucoid diarrhoea. Such a patient is highly unlikely to have a carcinoma because altered bowel habit is not a feature of right-sided colonic carcinoma

(BAILEY AND LOVE : 27th edition - Pg 58)

choices.text: Eggs reach liver via Portal circulation
Small bowel perforation is common in children

questions.text: A 10 year old male child presenting with abdominal pain, malnutrition with signs of intestinal obstruction. Child is from endemic region. Stool examination revealed multiple eggs of roundworm. True regarding life cycle are all except
questions.solution:
Small intestinal obstruction can occur, particularly in children, due to a bolus of adult worms incarcerated in the terminal ileum. This is a surgical emergency. Rarely, perforation of the small bowel may occur from ischaemic pressure necrosis from the bolus of worms

(BAILEY AND LOVE : 27th edition - Pg 60)

choices.text: Incision over bony prominence is preferable
Incision to be made parallel to Langer's lines

questions.text: An intern was about to perform sebaceous cyst excision. Factors to be considered before incision are all except
questions.solution:
When planning a skin incision, four factors should be considered:

  1. Skin tension lines (Langer's lines). These lines represent the orientation of the dermal collagen fibres and any incision placed parallel to these lines results in a better scar
  2. Anatomical structure. Incisions should avoid bony prominences and crossing skin creases if possible, and take into consideration underlying structures, such as nerves and vessels.
  3. Cosmetic factors. Any incision should be made bearing in mind the ultimate cosmetic result, especially in exposed parts of the body, as an incision is the only part of the operation the patient sees.
  4. Adequate access for the procedure. The incision must be functionally effective for the procedure in hand because any compromise purely on cosmetic grounds may render the operation ineffective or even dangerous

(BAILEY AND LOVE : 27th edition - Pg 85)

questions.text: In Trauma ward an intern was asked to choose a suture material for suturing of a lacerated wound. Characteristics of suture material are all except
questions.solution:
Suture material: desired characteristsics

  • Easy to handle
  • Predictable behaviour in tissues
  • Predictable tensile strength
  • Sterile
  • Glides through tissues easily
  • Secure knotting ability
  • Inexpensive
  • Minimal tissue reaction
  • Non-capillary
  • Non-allergenic
  • Non-carcinogenic
  • Non-electrolytic
  • Non-shrinkage

(BAILEY AND LOVE : 27th edition - Pg 89)

questions.text: A 20 year old male after chemical burns presented with black eschar. This type of wound healing is
questions.solution:
Types of wound healing

Primary intention

Clean wound

Secondary intention

Healthy granulation tissue

Overexuberant granulation tissue

Infected sloughy wound

Black eschar

Tertiary intention

Delayed closure Skin grafting

(BAILEY AND LOVE : 27th edition - Pg 89)

choices.text: Elasticity is returning of original length
Deformable is converting circular to oval shape
Memory is curling of suture material
More memory the suture, more knot security

questions.text: A Junior resident while suturing, material keeps curling and hindering the procedure. True regarding tensile behaviour are all except
questions.solution:
Suture materials behave differently depending upon their deformability and flexibility. Some may be 'elastic', where the material will return to its original length once any tension is released, while others may be 'plastic', in which case this phenomenon does not occur.

Sutures may be deformable, in that a circular cross-section may be converted to an oval shape, or they may be more rigid and have the somewhat irritating capacity to kink and coil.

Many synthetic materials demonstrate 'memory', so that they keep curling up in the shape they adopted within the packaging. A sharp but gentle pull on the suture material helps to diminish this memory, but the more memory a suture material has, the lower is the knot security.

Therefore, knotting technique also plays a significant role in any suture line's tensile strength and it is important to recognise that sutures lose 50% of their strength at the knot

(BAILEY AND LOVE : 27th edition - Pg 90)

questions.text: A vascular surgeon choose appropriate suture material for anastomoses. True statement is
questions.solution:
Vascular anastomosis

  • Non-absorbable monofilament suture material should be used, e.g. polypropylene
  • A smooth intimal suture line is essential
  • Knots require multiple throws in order to ensure security
  • The suture must pass from within outwards on the downflow aspect of the anastomosis

(BAILEY AND LOVE : 27th edition - Pg 99)

questions.text: After gastric perforation closure surgeon preferred to keep 2 drains intra abdominally. Following are true except
questions.solution:
the presence of a drain may:

  • increase intra-abdominal and wound infections;
  • increase anastomotic insufficiency;
  • increase abdominal pain;
  • increase hospital;
  • decrease pulmonary function;

(BAILEY AND LOVE : 27th edition - Pg 100)

questions.text: An established case of gall bladder calculus preferring for lap cholecystectomy. All are advantages of minimal access surgery except
questions.solution:
Advantages of minimal access surgery

  • Decrease in wound size
  • Reduction in wound infection, dehiscence, bleeding, herniation and nerve entrapment
  • Decrease in wound pain
  • Improved mobility
  • Decreased wound trauma
  • Decreased heat loss
  • Improved visualisation

questions.text: A patient is planned for lap bowel resection. All are true regarding limitation of minimal access surgery except
questions.solution:
When there is intraoperative arterial bleeding, haemostasis may be very difficult to achieve endoscopically because blood obscures the field of vision and there is a significant reduction of the image quality due to light absorption.

Another disadvantage of laparoscopic surgery is the loss of tactile feedback

(BAILEY AND LOVE : 27th edition - Pg 107)

questions.text: An infant was evaluated for surgery under general anaesthesia. All are false regarding upper airway except
questions.solution:
Loose teeth

Large tongue

Narrow nostrils

Compressible floor of mouth

Horseshoe - shaped epiglottis

questions.text: What is true regarding starvation for infant who has been prepared for surgery under general anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
Fasting instructions

  • Two hours for clear fluids
  • Four hours for breast milk
  • Six hours for solids

questions.text: A long standing ulcer suddenly shows ulceroproliferative growth. Past history of burns+. All are features of malignant transformation except
questions.solution:
Features of malignant transformation

  • Establish an autonomous lineage Resist signals that inhibit growth Sustain proliferative signalling
  • Obtain replicative immortality
  • Evade apoptosis
  • Acquire angiogenic competence
  • Acquire ability to invade
  • Acquire ability to disseminate and implant
  • Evocation of inflammation
  • Evade detection/elimination
  • Jettison excess baggage
  • Subvert communication to and from the cellular environment
  • Develop ability to change energy metabolism

questions.text: A surgeon completed Modified radical mastectomy which of the following suture material is used to put Subcuticular sutures?
questions.solution:
Polyglycolic Acid: (Vicryl) - Workshop material in theatre

  • Multifilament material (Made up of Glycolic acid+ Lactic acid co polymers)- as it is multifilament it has good knotting capacity but increased infection.
  • Violet color
  • Absorption period- 60 - 90 days
  • Absorbed by Hydrolysis
  • Types of Vicryl:
    • Barbed Vicryl-No knotting needed, Used in Facelift sutures, plastic surgery
    • Vicryl plus- Antibiotic coated (Trichlosan antibiotic)
    • Vicryl Rapide-Absorbed in 10 days
    • White Vicryl (MONOCRYL)-Poly glycaprone (Monofilament material)-Suture of choice for Subcuticular sutures in Skin (Cosmetic Skin Closure)
  • Applications:
    • Bowel Anastomosis (3'0 vicryl)
    • Bile duct anastomosis (4'0 Vicryl)
    • Muscle closure
    • Subcutaneous closure
    • Vicryl Meshes (Inner side of Dual Mesh to prevent bowel Adhesions)
  • Pancreatic duct- Vicryl must not be used (use only prolene or PDS)

choices.text: Memory is a property of Prolene suture
Catgut is stored in Isopropyl alcohol
Poly-diaxonone is absorbed after 180 days by hydrolysis

questions.text: Regarding the properties of various suture materials- False statement is:
questions.solution:
Polyglycolic acid - Vicryl is a multifilament material

(Ref. Bailey 27th Edition page 93)

questions.text: Mrs Kumari underwent gastrectomy for carcinoma stomach- and abdomen closure was planned. The laparotomy wound length was measured. It is 15 cm in length. The surgeon now decides to close the abdomen using a Prolene 1 size. What should be the minimum length of the suture to close the abdomen wound
questions.solution:
jenkin's rule:

The length of suture needed to close the abdomen is equal to 4X length of wound

So here- 15X4 = 60 cm

(Ref. Bailey and Love 27th Edition page 90)

Cheatle cut- The cut done on small circumference bowel for an end to end anastomosis. Usually done in Ileo colic anastomosis

questions.solution:

questions.text: What is the surgery probably done for this patient from the incision shown?
questions.solution:
This is rooftop incision known as Chevron (used for Pancreatic surgery)

(Ref. Bailey 27th Edition Page 86)

questions.text: Which among the following Diathermy Currents have more coagulation property?
questions.solution:
• Blended- Mixture of Continuous and Damped Sine wave.
  • More continuous will have more cutting and more damped will have more coagulation
  • Blend 1 50:50
  • Blend 2 40:60
  • Blend 3 25:75 (More coagulating)

(Ref. Bailey 27th Edition Page 102)

choices.text: This is a safety valve tipped needle known as Veress needle
The maximum air flow that can be made is only 2.5 litres/minute
There is high risk of bowel injury using this needle compared to Hassan cannula
Major vessel injury risk is more than Hassan cannula

questions.text: Regarding this instrument used to create Pneumoperitoneum- False statement is
questions.solution:
Laparoscopic Surgery:

  • Insufflation of gas in peritoneal cavity and operating via small holes.
  • Gases used : Carbon Dioxide(MC), Nitrogen, Air
  • Carbon dioxide is rapidly absorbable and causes less post-operative pain and less incidence of Fat embolism
  • CO2 is 200 times more diffusible and rapidly cleared from circulation
  • Intraperitoneal pressure maintained during surgery- 12-15 mmHg
  • Laparoscopy pneumo peritoneum is created by 2 methods: Open and Closed method

(Ref. Bailey and love 27th Edition Page 112)



Complications of Laparoscopy:

  • Primary cannula (1st Cannula Insertion)- Injury to Bowel, Blood Vessel, Stomach, Bladder, Mesentry, Diaphragm, AORTA, IVC, Epigastric vessels are injury (MC in Secondary Cannula)
  • Secondary cannulas (Under vision inserted)- Epigastric vessel injury MC

questions.text: A patient named Mr Ramu was operate for a inguinal hernia by laparoscopic method, by TAPP method comes to you with abdominal distension, guarding and rigidity on 3rd POD. During laparoscopy, a metal trocar with plastic sheath is used. What problem might have happened during surgery based on above line
questions.solution:
Capacitance Coupling Injury:

  • On sandwich of the insulator between two metal electrodes - A capacitor is created.
  • This occurs when we pass a metal hook into a metal made Port. By electromagnetic induction current is created and there is a damage to abdominal viscera.
  • Patient Presents with delayed leak
  • Plastic ports avoids this injury

(Ref. Bailey 27th Edition Page 103)

choices.text: Currently available master slave Robot is da Vinci Robot
There is huge ergonomics and comfort for surgeon compared to laparoscopy
Tactile sensation is better than a laparoscopic surgery

questions.text: Regarding Robotic surgery-False statement is:
questions.solution:
Robotic Surgery:

Davinci Robot



  • Docking- Inserting the limbs of Robot inside
  • Major Advantages:
    • Eliminates tremors of the surgeon
    • Multidirectional movement- 7 degree freedom
    • Tele robotic Surgery can be done

(Ref Bailey and Love 27th Edition Page 109)
